intro: Lippia globiflora var. normalis, commonly known as the globeflower lippia, is a species native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring aromatic, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, tubular flowers that are usually white or pale blue, blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a suitable candidate for xeriscaping and native plant gardens. The plant is also valued for its use in traditional medicine and as a source of essential oils.
